qas.question: What areas experience periodic flooding from rapid snowmelt and runoff?

answers.text: The areas that are not arid and receive high precipitation

qas.question: What are the ranges of mean precipitation in the Alps?

answers.text: 2,600 mm (100 in) per year to 3,600 mm (140 in) per year

qas.question: Where do the higher levels of precipitation occur?
At what altitude does snowfall begin in November?

context: <a0_0>The areas that are not arid and receive high precipitation<a0_0/> experience periodic flooding from rapid snowmelt and runoff. The mean precipitation in the Alps ranges from a low of <a1_0>2,600 mm (100 in) per year to 3,600 mm (140 in) per year<a1_0/>, with the higher levels occurring at <a2_0>high altitudes<a2_0/>. <a3_0>At altitudes between 1,000 and 3,000 m<a3_0/> (3,281 and 9,843 ft), snowfall begins in November and accumulates through to April or May when the melt begins. Snow lines vary from 2,400 to 3,000 m (7,874 to 9,843 ft), above which the snow is permanent and the temperatures hover around the freezing point even July and August. High-water levels in streams and rivers peak in June and July when the snow is still melting at the higher altitudes.
